txt.en: Complete deeds in Eriador to earn Honour

You have joined <rgb=#00D0FF>Elladan's</rgb> faction in 'The Tournament of the Twins' and may now do battle with <rgb=#FF0000>Elrohir's</rgb> faction members!\n- Complete deeds in Eriador to earn Honour.\n- You may be harassed and hunted by member's of <rgb=#FF0000>Elrohir's</rgb> faction!

'Sauron is no more, but we must not let this triumph lull us into too-secure a peace! His servants were many and they will remain a danger for the Free Peoples of Middle-earth. It is for this reason that my brother and I have sanctioned a great contest by which heroes will test their mettle and their skills, the better to challenge the servants of evil that remain.

'So, do you wish to take up arms for <rgb=#00D0FF>Elladan</rgb>, son of Elrond? I would be honoured for you to fight on my behalf!'

<rgb=#00FF00>
The Rules of the Contest:
- If you accept this quest, you will become an active member of </rgb><rgb=#00D0FF>Elladan's</rgb><rgb=#00FF00> faction.
- Members of </rgb><rgb=#FF0000>Elrohir's</rgb><rgb=#00FF00> faction will appear as hostile to you, and you will be able to fight them.
- You receive Honour for every Eriador deed completed while you are an active member of either faction.
</rgb>
'There can be no failure while we stand true.'

To celebrate the downfall of Sauron, the sons of Elrond have challenged the heroes of Middle-earth to a contest of strength, cunning, and wit. These heroes will pledge their abilities to either Elladan or Elrohir's banner, engaging in honourable battle with those who pledge to their rival, all while striving to complete as many deeds as possible throughout Eriador.
 
<rgb=#00FF00>
The Rules of the Contest:
- You have joined </rgb><rgb=#FF0000>Elladan's</rgb><rgb=#00FF00> faction.
- Members of </rgb><rgb=#00D0FF>Elrohir's</rgb><rgb=#00FF00> faction will appear as hostile to you, and you will be able to fight them.
- You receive Honour for every Eriador deed completed while you are an active member of either faction.
</rgb>
'It is good to see you again. How goes the contest of honour, my friend?'
